description: From im- +‎ prudence. From Middle French imprudence, from Latin imprudentia.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) The quality or state of being imprudent; lack of prudence, caution, discretion or circumspection.

examples: Ah: my dear—Madam there is the great mistake—'tis this very conscious Innocence that is of the greatest Prejudice to you—what is it makes you negligent of Forms and careless of the world's opinion—why the consciousness of your Innocence—what makes you thoughtless in your Conduct and apt to run into a thousand little imprudences—
